goals.question: What is the distribution of terrain types in the platformer game?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the frequency of different terrain types in the game and identify any patterns or imbalances.

goals.question: What is the average length of each level in the platformer game?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the distribution of level lengths and identify any outliers or trends.

goals.question: What is the correlation between the difficulty of a level and the number of enemies in the level?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot of difficulty and number of enemies
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there is a relationship between the difficulty of a level and the number of enemies, which can inform level design decisions.

goals.question: What is the most common power-up in the platformer game?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the frequency of different power-up types in the game and identify any imbalances or opportunities for improvement.

goals.question: What is the distribution of player deaths across levels in the platformer game?
goals.visualization: Box plot of player deaths by level
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the spread and central tendency of player deaths across levels, which can inform level design decisions and difficulty balancing.

code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    terrain_counts = data['terrain_type'].value_counts()
    terrain_counts.plot(kind='bar', color=['blue', 'green', 'red', 'cyan', 'magenta', 'yellow', 'black', 'white'])
    plt.xlabel('Terrain Types')
    plt.ylabel('Frequency')
    plt.title('What is the distribution of terrain types in the platformer game?', wrap=True)
    plt.legend(terrain_counts.index, title='Terrain Types', loc='upper right')
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    # Calculate the average length of each level
    avg_lengths = data.groupby('level')['length'].mean()

    # Create a histogram of the average level lengths
    plt.hist(avg_lengths, bins=10, color='blue', alpha=0.7, label='Level Lengths')
    
    # Add a vertical line for the overall average length
    overall_avg = avg_lengths.mean()
    plt.axvline(overall_avg, color='red', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=2, label=f'Overall Avg: {overall_avg:.2f}')
    
    # Set the title, labels, and legend
    plt.title('What is the average length of each level in the platformer game?', wrap=True)
    plt.xlabel('Average Level Length')
    plt.ylabel('Frequency')
    plt.legend()
    
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    plt.scatter(data['difficulty'], data['number_of_enemies'])
    plt.xlabel('Difficulty')
    plt.ylabel('Number of Enemies')
    plt.title('What is the correlation between the difficulty of a level and the number of enemies in the level?', wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    powerup_counts = data['power_up_type'].value_counts()
    plt.pie(powerup_counts, labels=powerup_counts.index, autopct='%1.1f%%')
    plt.title('What is the most common power-up in the platformer game?', wrap=True)
    plt.legend(powerup_counts.index, title="Power-up Types", loc="best")
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
    sns.boxplot(x='level', y='player_deaths', data=data)
    plt.title('What is the distribution of player deaths across levels in the platformer game?', wrap=True)
    plt.xlabel('Level')
    plt.ylabel('Player Deaths')
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)
